And I really love that.
So that's one, and it could be divisive if we changed them to elder, to the name to elder,
but they serve like elders.
And I know that that's splitting a hair a little bit, but sometimes it's called for.
And then we also have women who are in that role.
And that is a divisive thing in the church is whether that should be the case.
And I think we unpacked this in detail under some of the podcasts about women serving in
ministry.
But to shortcut it, so one, go back and listen to that if that's interesting to you, but
to shortcut it, both elder and deacon have the phrase husband, they're both told in the
masculine, and they both have the phrase husband of one wife.
The reason that is open to conversation is because then later, Paul references in Romans
16, he references a woman who is a deacon he is honoring.
And she's the deacon of a specific church.
So it sure sounds like husband of one wife was not meant to disqualify women, at least
in regards to deacons.
Now we don't have any examples of a woman who is an elder who's listed as an elder.
There's one listed as being quote, among the apostles, which freaks a lot of people
out, but which is hard enough, but we don't have one listed.
Now, there's a lot of gray area in this.
So because Paul honors a woman who is a deacon, calls her a deacon and the deacon of a certain
church, he honors her, it sure seems like the phrase husband of one wife, at least in
regards to deacons does not mean men only.
Well, if husband of one wife doesn't mean men only for deacons, then it's at least a
potential that husband of one wife doesn't mean men only for elders.
But it's an area of contentious division in the church to discuss that, which is totally
appropriate for us to fight about it.
And because it's not abundantly clear in my opinion.
So one, in an effort to avoid unnecessary division, what we do is we have selected these
people to serve in an elder role, though they are not referred to as elders, referred to
as leadership board.
But we use the elder office as a representative, as the descriptor of who they are.
Now, to make it even weirder, here's what's weird in the Baptist church.
And I didn't know this.
I've been in like four denominations in my lifetime.
But in the Baptist church, I am the elder.
So in a Baptist church, the tradition is that the teaching pastor or teaching pastors are
the only actual elders in a church.
So they take the passage that says that the elders have to be, the Episcopalists have
to be able to teach the Word of God.
And they say, therefore, if part of your job description is to teach the Word of God, then
you're an elder.
So like in South Spring, the traditional perspective, Paul McKenzie and I would be the only two
elders in this church.
If you go by that, which fine, I mean, it's not how the decision, but I would disagree
with that Paul and I should be the decision makers in the church.
That should be members of the church from within the body, not just a couple of staff
members.
And so I get the confusion.
And part of this is we are trying to apply what Paul taught 2000 years ago to a brand
new faith, creating brand new churches.
And we are faithfully all trying to figure out.
And I, by the way, but I mean that I think most people are faithfully trying to apply
his teachings in their local church.
So what we have are that eight person team and that's the decision making team at South
Spring.
I am not aware of another church that set up exactly like us.
When I do leaders, lead pastors meetings periodically, every one of them is different.
It's amazing the different church polity that's created in different churches.
And some work well and some are probably a train wreck, but here this has worked really
well.
Though we are not, this is not the only way to understand or interpret or apply these
passages and may not even be the most obvious ways to do so.
We think it is a faithful way of doing so.
And then deacons, we have deacons at the church and their job is to serve.
They have no quote, political leadership at all.
They have no decision making outside of their own group.
And what I love too, so I'm a deacon and I love that.
As I was reading First Timothy 3, I feel like it goes along with the way South Spring does
it is that it is highlighting people who are already serving and showing, hey, these are
some people that we could follow.
You could walk in the way that they're doing things.
And so I love that because what that does is it really encourages us to say, hey, we
see what you're doing, keep doing it.
And so I feel encouraged by that and want to keep serving because they've said, hey,
keep going.
That was a funny thing.
One of the funny things about this, so applying the elder conversation in Episcopals is very
complicated.
What makes the deacon one complicated is you think, aren't all Christians supposed to be
deacons?
How is that a title?
And what we've decided is we take people who are deacons, meaning they serve.
They serve faithfully in different ways.
And what we do is say, we now want to make it official so that we can point you out.
So then people say, what does it mean to serve at our church?
I can go, well, look at Jordan, he's a deacon.
I want you to serve like he serves.
And so that you become a leader in service.
And that's really what a deacon in a church is.
Everybody's supposed to be serving, but the leaders in service, not the leaders of the
church, but the leaders that are showing the church how to serve, those are your deacons.
That's the plan, at least.
And again, as Bryn said, and as we've said so many times, we have to deconstruct our
faith in humans because of course, this gets messed up.
And anytime you involve humans, it's going to get messed up.
So I think this question applies to what you just said then.
So there's a pretty good list for both of these of qualifications.
Right?
So talk about, is this, in general, when I think about so and so, these are the qualifications
they have.
And so specifically, what I'm trying to think of is if someone stumbles in one of these
areas at one point, but then is maybe, I don't know, repentant or...
Talk about how do you look at someone and say, these are your qualifications of this
huge list.
So one, we're still at the place where we feel the luxury of engaging with each of those
conversations as a standalone versus saying, well, this person had a divorce in their life,
so they're out.
Or this person is an alcoholic in recovery, oh, but they had a bad weekend, now they're
out.
And so instead of going, okay, we're going to set a set, create a new Torah with a whole
bunch of rules and then go, okay, you're, yeah, no, you're cut.
Now you're cut.
What we do is we, as a leader, this is one of the jobs of our leadership board, is to
engage with each of these.
And very often it means...
So this is what it revealed that's so powerful is you want to have those conversations with
friends who love you.
And so if you're not being friends with and loving those people, if no one is being friends
with and loving those people who are really struggling, but who also have the capacity
to lead, then what that means is there's no one there who can have that conversation.
And so I've gotten to have the conversation recently like, hey, we all love you and we
think you'd make a great leader, but you had this big mess up in your life a couple of
years ago, and we're going to ask you to give it more time.
Let's wait another year or two before we talk about you going into leadership.
Let's make sure your things are still good.
That's not a fun conversation to have.
So you want it to be with someone who knows you love them.
And so that's part of what we do is at the leadership board level, if there's someone
who we see nominated for something and we're like, yeah, he probably or she probably shouldn't
have let themselves be nominated, then we go to that person.
And I've had to have some uncomfortable conversations certainly saying, listen, it makes clear that
this is not someone who is, for example, drunkenness is not an issue for them, that they're experiencing
victory in regards to the addictive things in their lives.
There's probably a big application of that, but certainly grows to alcohol.
And I've had to say, I've seen you around, I've spent enough time with you and I think
probably you're dancing on this edge.
And so I love you.
I want you part of our church.
I want you involved in these things, but I don't think you being on the leadership board
is a good idea right now.
And that's tough.
Or you know what?
You're kind of a divisive person and I think you like to quarrel and that's your thing.
I mean, you like picking fights online and you like causing, you know, you're kind of
an online, you know, internet troll and that's, and listen, if that's your thing, fine.
Like that's not, that's not, I'm not telling you, you can't do that.
I'm just saying not quarrelsome is one of the requirements for this.
And so I think you need to decide, do you want to have that reputation?
And if you do, great, then don't let anybody nominate you for leadership board or to be
a deacon.
If you don't, or you've got a huge crisis going on in your home, your kids are out of
control.
Like here's what I'm going to recommend you do instead of joining leadership board or
being a deacon.
What I'm going to recommend that you do is once you take that time and either get training
or counseling or something to learn how to manage your home better or just spend that
time with your kids.
And so I think there's a lot of pragmatic, there's a lot of spiritual holiness issues
in regards to it.
There's a lot of pragmatic issues, but here's what it isn't, Jordan is, man, you've got
to have it all together.
You can't serve.
You can't be struggling with any of these areas or you can't serve because then none
of us would get to serve.
All of us are, if you read through that list and you go, man, I'm nailing this, you are
certainly not welcome on any role of leadership or service at the church.
If you think you're nailing them, then that's a huge, that seems like a much bigger warning
side.
If you go like that, I feel like I generally have Victor in these areas and here's the
one or two that I struggle with the most and I eat too much or sometimes I fall in
the temptation of pornography or whatever, but here's what I'm doing to fight that and
struggle against that and then you go, okay, well then that sounds like you're trying to
live the disciples' life.
But again, the failure, if you look at your leadership and you say, oh man, he must have
it all together or they wouldn't let him be the lead pastor.
Yeah, don't do that.
You're just setting yourself up for your faith to be built on something other than
Christ.
That's good.
So that's interesting.
What I was really interested in, so that makes sense within the church to have people you
can see that are setting good examples, but also are real and struggling and you can follow
in those examples.
There's a mention about the overseers too is that they are thought of well by outsiders.
Yeah, that's interesting.
Can you speak to that?
Why is that important?
So I think there's a couple of things the way that plays out is the reason you want
especially those who are leading in the church to have a good reputation is that yes, there
will be some people who don't like you, but that's always going to be the case.
But if your general reputation in the community is that you're an unkind person or not a generous
person or just kind of a big jerk, then yeah, that's a hard...
People are going to link that, your character flaws to the gospel and they're going to say,
well, I can't go to that church because of this guy.
And all churches face that and we struggle with how do we let people serve who are broken
and jacked up and everything else, but how do we also tell them, listen, we can't let
you be one of our forward facing leaders in the church because your reputation is...
You're dishonest.
I mean, you run a kind of business and the way you operate in your business, you're thought
of as a dishonest person.
And so what are we saying if we put you in a position of leadership?
And again, that's really tough and those are tough conversations to have.
And a lot of times you can expect, so you're going to get the response you get anytime
you confront somebody on something.
You're either going to say, oh my gosh, you're right.
I need to change that or I don't know how to change or whatever.
Or they're going to say, you know what, if you don't want me to play, I'll take my ball
and go home.
Right.
And which is just probably creates a healthier church when that does happen.
As hard as it is, it's also probably...
And it may make another church a little bit less healthy.
I have one last question.
I think that'll be a good wrap up kind of question.
So those not in these positions or able to be in these positions or you know, U13s or
anything like that, how does this apply to them?
Like what do they learn from this passage?
Is it just, okay, that's my authority.
I need to learn to trust that.
Or is there anything on just leadership principles in general that we should take from that?
Oh gosh.
Here's a couple.
So one that comes to mind is I would definitely want to jump over to the first Peter five
reference to the fact that those who seek to be an overseer, that that is a healthy
ambition.
And so it would be healthy for teenagers to say, someday I want to be in a role of leadership
in my church.
Like, okay, well, what are decisions you can be making now that help make that happen?
That's one.
Two, to recognize, I think these are some pretty big standards.
We ought to be praying for the people who are in leadership.
We ought to be encouraging them, supporting them, even when we have to ask hard questions.
Those two definitely come to mind.
And then I do think there is a third one that says you want to follow the leadership of
authority in the same way you would want to be followed if you were the person in authority.
I'm trying to remember what Hebrews passage it is.
We may have to find it real quick, but there's a Hebrews passage, I feel like it's very near
the end, maybe chapter 13, that references that it should be a joy to lead God's people.
I bet we could, we can probably find that real quick.
And so are you asking the students, are you a joy to your Sunday school teachers?
Did you find it?
Remember your leaders, consider the outcome of their way of life, imitate their faith.
That's good.
We'd have to look for that.
But it talks about how it should be.
I should know this.
Okay, obey your leader, submit to them for their keeping watch over your souls as those who have
to give an account.
Let them do this with joy and not with groaning for that would be of no advantage to you.
There you go.
Hebrews 13, 17.
Perfect.
So that's the one I was thinking.
That whole passage really is a fascinating little, hey, you're not in leadership right
now.
So here's what it looks like to lead when you're not in leadership.
And so that's a great encouragement.
Is it a joy to be your Sunday school teacher?
Is it a joy to be a deacon in the church where you are?
Is it a joy to be your student minister?
And I think that's a great question for kids to ask.
And even for Christian kids to be asked, is it a joy to be your teacher at school?
Or do you make their life, you know, living hell?
And so Christian kids should be a joy to be led at school to.
Now that doesn't mean they don't stand up for what's right.
Of course they do.
It doesn't mean they don't, you know, there's certain times that you have to, you might
have to defy leadership.
But even then it should be done respectfully.
So there's some good, that's a lot of cover.
Anyway, that gives you a good insight kind of into how we do it in some of these big
pictures.
And it also shows how easy it would be for someone to experience anything other than
a healthy version of that.
And the temptation is to say, well, if that's the church, if that's God, well, then I don't
want anything to do with it.
And I can't tell you how many people I've heard who have come to our church and then
said like, I'm so afraid of everything's going to fall apart.
We're going to have a split.
We're going to all these bad things they've experienced in church leadership.
And I get it.
And there's a lot of trauma involved in that.
I've been there.
I've experienced it from the inside too.
And once again, we just have to delineate between what is God and what are God's people
who are jacked up and what are even people who aren't God's people, but who are part
of His church.
And there's plenty of lost people in the church too that are going to sometimes make life
really tough.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
at southspring.org.
Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up.
Trust God.
Search for answers.
Go to www.reconstructedfaith.org.
For more information, visit www.reconstructedfaith.org.
Thank you.
For more information, visit www.reconstructedfaith.org.
